title: Libcurl ocasionally sends HTTPS traffic to port 443 rather than specified port 8080

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is a computer software project providing a library and command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
We have encountered an issue with libcurl where, under certain network conditions, the library will attempt to submit data to an incorrect port as was set by CURLOPT_PORT. As information is sent to an unauthorised port, we consider this an information disclosure issue.

Our security software encompasses a Windows application (an agent) that runs as a Windows service. Its purpose is to collect custom metrics from the machine, such as IO operations (file reads, file writes, ...), process start/stops, user login, and some other forensic info. We use libcurl to communicate with a server over HTTPS.

A customer with ~5000 our agents raised an issue that approx 0.5% of all traffic is sent to port 443. In our application, we only use port 8080. Each request is made with source code (nearly identical) to the one I attach to this report.

This client uses Windows DNS load balancing. An agent will make a request to a local DNS server and the server will return an IP of one of the 5 servers based on round-robin. All servers have a web server running and our server-side application working on port 8080. 

We were unable to pin-point exactly which network conditions trigger this issue reliably, however, we have been able to reproduce it in a production environment with logging enabled. This could potentially be triggered by a slow server response or when the web server is down.

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Configure a round-robin DNS load balancing
  2. Make a high number of small HTTPS request to port 8080
  3. [Potentially] Server fails to handle a response [exact conditions were not established]
  4. Approx 0.5% of all traffic will be directed to port 443, under the hood, without application instructions

## Supporting Material/References:

- Example source code
- Log sample showing the `primary port` is changed to 443

## Versions
- OS: Windows 10 x64

Libraries
- curl:x86-windows-static                            7.61.1-7        
- curl[http2]:x86-windows-static                                     
- curl[openssl]:x86-windows-static                                   
- curl[ssl]:x86-windows-static                                       
- curl[winssl]:x86-windows-static                                    
- fmt:x86-windows-static                             5.3.0-1         
- gtest:x86-windows-static                           2019-01-04-2    
- nghttp2:x86-windows-static                         1.35.0          
- nlohmann-json:x86-windows-static                   3.6.1           
- openssl-windows:x86-windows-static                 1.0.2q-2        
- openssl:x86-windows-static                         0               
- rapidcheck:x86-windows-static                      2018-11-05-1    
- rapidxml:x86-windows-static                        1.13            
- spdlog:x86-windows-static                          1.3.1           
- zlib:x86-windows-static                            1.2.11-5

## Impact

An attacker must have access to the authorised server, for example, be a local admin. 

The server is expected to run a web app on a port other than 443, for example, port 8080. 

A client application will send traffic to only port 8080. But libcurl will occasionally send traffic to port 443. 

If an attacker set up a web app on port 443, they will receive some traffic (0.5%) that was supposed to be sent to a different port.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, we'll investigate.

I'm puzzled. This using the wrong port number has never been reported before and I can't understand it. It also doesn't actually prove that port 443 was used, the sample code outputs what libcurl says was used. I've not been able to reproduce this issue and I can't find the source code where this can happen. Anyone else?

Thank you for looking into this. Something that could aid troubleshooting:

If we look at the following log entries
```
[2019-May-13T07:47:02] [7592] [info] CurlFacade::Post req http post https://srv.example.com/api/stream:8080     [193 bytes]
[2019-May-13T07:47:02] [7592] [info] CurlFacade::Post req additional details: effective url: https://srv.example.com/api/stream || primary ip:  || 
[2019-May-13T07:47:23] [7592] [info] CurlFacade::Post resp http post https://srv.example.com/api/stream:8080. Curl = 0. Response code = 404
[2019-May-13T07:47:23] [7592] [info] CurlFacade::Post resp additional details: request port: 8080 || response code: 404 || effective url: https://srv.example.com/api/stream || primary port: 443 || 

Line 1: a request is being made to HTTPS endpoint using FQDN and a specific port 8080 set via CURLOPT_PORT
Line 2: a printout of effective URL and primary ip, which is not resolved at this moment

<Then we call  curl_easy_perform(curl)>
<notice it takes about 21 seconds, so the server is down or not responsive, we expect 100s of millisecond replies in normal flow>

Line 3: a response is received from an IIS webserver with response code 404

<This is because there is another application bounded to port 443 that does not understand this url https://srv.example.com/api/stream>
<In our setup IIS hosts two different web apps, one on 8080, another one on 443>

Line 4: a response additional details that have a primary port value set to 443
```

In line 4, it appears that libcurl has somehow changed the port (that was set via CURLOPT_PORT to 8080) to a default HTTPS port 443.

I'm just trying to add some assistance to @bagder here as I run IIS myself however I'm a little confused by the sample output and matching code.

1) In the code you are outputting the contents of "url" which is set to "https://srv.example.com/api/stream".

However you have told curl to use "https://server1.prod.example.com/api/stream".

As such I would expect effective url to be the latter and not the former or are the two pointing at the same IP/machine?

2) Are you still using load balancing in the test environment?

3) Are you able to turn verbose logging on inside libcurl?

4) I'm also curious as to why the body length appears to be 190 and 193?

to @captain_caveman2k 

1) The log files were taken from the customer and sanitised to remove DNS entries which would reveal the customer name. It was my poor sanitisation that resulted in misrepresentation in the demo log and demo code. The URL that is used by the customer matches the following pattern
`https://<componentname>.<productname>.<customername>.com/api/stream`
Output in the real log matches the set URL.

2) Yes, we are.

3) This is a good call, could you please point me to docs and tell me which log level to use. Getting new logs may take several days from the customer. Thank you.

4) This is the actual length of the gzip compressed json object that we send. It varies approx between 100 bytes - 100 KB, mostly depending on the IO load on the machine. An example payload looks like this:

(Typically the payload will be compressed and content-encoding will be "gzip".)
```
POST http://<server>:8080/api/stream
X-API-Version: 3.0
Authorization: Bearer <token>
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Content-Encoding: text
[
   {
   "d":"2016-02-01T13:15:30Z",
   "m":"id123",
   "u":"bob",
   "ap":"notepad.exe",
   "ac":"file written",
   "r": "c:\\temp\\foo.txt" 
   }, 
   { /* similar events to the one above */ }
]
```
That protocol example uses a HTTP proxy and a HTTP://  URL in there. Is that really what your app is sending? Your earlier code sample did neither?
`CURLOPT_VERBOSE` is a boolean so it has no levels. It's `1L` for **ON** and `0L` for **OFF**.

I converted your example code into a plain C version (attached) that I can run against my local nginx installation. It runs on my port 8443 so it seems like it should then be able to reproduce this. No matter how many iterations I try to run this, not a single one has showed/reproduced this described problem (running libcurl from git master).
As explained, I can't reproduce.

We received the logs from the customer. The curl debug log shows some traffic to 443. We've had to sanitise the log file to remove customer identity, apart from that the log has not been modified.

If you search the log for "port 443" you will be able to see this, for example, line 4673.

Please let me know if you need more information. Thank you.

1. You show a log from your app, I wrote an app that I can't make reproduce the same results
2. The log says that libcurl *extracted port 443 after a connection*, it didn't actually prove that it used port 443 in a connection attempt (like in a PCAP/wireshark trace or similar). It could just as well be libcurl just reporting the wrong port after a connection. Or perhaps even another bug that makes 443 appear in the log there.

Since we cannot reproduce and we have not detected or found suspicious source code that we can investigate, we have simply don't have enough to work with here. This is simply not enough for us to act on. I will agree that it smells of a possible bug in libcurl somewhere, but without more data it is just a theory for now.

I will therefore recommend that we close this issue for now, and if we can figure out more details or more information that will reveal something we can reopen it again - or even file a new issue then.

From our side we have:

1) Curl verbose log that mentions port 443
2) We have IIS server logs that show traffic designated to API port (8080) hitting a web site port (443)
3) We do not use port 443 for any API calls in the code, each call has a specific port 8080 set by a `curl port` option
4) A customer runs an enterprise firewall that detected data being sent to port 443
5) There is a screenshot attached that a connection is established to port 443 by our application, but nowhere in code or configuration we use port 443. Usually, there is a single connection to one server on port 8080.

I can provide additional evidence of 2 and 4 if required. 

I agree it's a problem that this issue is hard to reproduce, but it does happen, and I do not agree with this issue being closed. CURL is used in numerous applications around the world, it would be a shame to expose even some fraction of the userbase to data leaks like this.

Let's work on this together, how can I help moving this forward?

> how can I help moving this forward?

If you run my example code, can you make it trigger and output lines that show the reported mismatch? If so, on what system using what libcurl version? If not, how do we modify my example code to make it reproduce this problem on systems and servers we control?

A log from your user using your application is not good enough for us. We need to reproduce this to find the culprit in the code in order to work on it. So far, it sounds like your user is the only one so far that have seen this problem, and that's unfortunately not enough.

If see that you're running a slightly older libcurl version (7.61.1) and I've not tried finding this problem on that particular version (nor do I test this on Windows in fact). There's a chance this problem changed nature in 7.62.0 when we introduced the new URL API/parser and these things were changed quite a bit internally. Can you reproduce this with 7.62.0 or later?

Alternatively, a code review could find a suspicious code path that could explain the behavior the log seems to imply. I'm the main author of this code and I've read it many times and I have not found any flaws that would explain this. The fact that even though libcurl is very widely used, nobody else has reported this problem so I would dare to suggest that it is rather rare (if it indeed is a curl issue).

The code example is pretty much what we have running. I could get it running but I will need to modify it to allow authentication and also it needs to send valid data. 

We also weren't able to reproduce this issue internally, but it is something that is quite easy to reproduce in production with our customer. 

Customer is using Windows 10 x64 systems with libcurl 7.61.1. I will speak with them to see if there is a way to organise access to a test system where you could see this issue. 

I think it is also possible for us to share real code if we could get NDA in place - would that be possible? You will be able to check which calls are made and if there is a way to insert any other debugging callbacks. 

I can build our application using CURL 7.65.2-1 which is the latest available from `vcpkg` (a package manager that we use for dependencies), shall I do it?

> I can build our application using CURL 7.65.2-1 which is the latest available from vcpkg (a package manager that we use for dependencies), shall I do it?

Yes please. It would be *very* valuable to learn if the issue is still present when using that version.
OK, I will do that, will report on the results. Thank you.

I've built our software using version `7.65.2-DEV` and the issue does not appear to be present. There were no indications in the log file that the data was sent to port 443.

I am tempted to do a bit more testing with the customer, to ensure it is definitely a version upgrade that fixed it and not some other change in their environment. But it looks like the issue is fixed in newer libcurl version.

Would you like me to do anything else?

As long as we can't reproduce the problem or agree that it exists based on a source code analysis, we cannot act on this. If it isn't even reproducible for you anymore it makes it a much less concern - and also it won't be subject for a bounty either even if it eventually turns out proven to have been present in the past. I think this issue is therefore subject for closure once you've run your tests enough to make you certain that it doesn't happen for you anymore.

(For the record: I ran the test code 50000 iterations with a libcurl 7.61.1 build too on my machine without seeing it trigger.)

I agree this issue is subject for closure, given there is evidence the issue is not present in the later release and it is hard to reproduce in the older releases. 

Please keep this ticket open for 1 week to allow us to get more data and confirm with tests. This may be helpful for others in case a similar issue is reported. 

Thank you for your help, and your time spent investigating this issue. We appreciate your efforts.
Sure no problem, I'm setting this issue back to "needs more info" and you can tell us your status in a week and we decide on how to act then!
@omdr any news? If not, I think we can close this now and if anything pops up again at a later point we reopen it or just create a new issue!
We have not received any news. Please close the issue. Thank you for all the time you have put into this one!
Doesn't seem to exist (anymore). Closing.
Happy for this to be disclosed. Thanks.
